prospects.name: Endurance 5
prospects.description:
The goal of this workout is to help develop your baseline aerobic fitness. While we are all about the High-Intensity Interval Training that most of our videos dish out, there are just times in a well-structured training plan that a proper Endurance/Base ride is just what your body needs.

This session will add minimal fatigue to your system, while still giving your aerobic engine the workload it needs to continue progressing. Steady Long Endurance rides are one of the best ways to cap off a long 2 or 3-week training block when your fatigue is high, your legs are tired, but you have just a bit more to squeeze out of yourself before you take your rest week, but only if you do it right!

Most people ride too hard when they head out for their "base miles." Truth be told, a proper Zone 2 ride should not leave you fatigued or your legs wasted. So what does a "proper" Zone 2 ride look like?

For 90% of the ride, you should stay between 55% and 65% of your FTP, at times going up to 70% is ok, but not over. (To spice things up, we have broken this session into 10-minute segments alternating from 60 to 65% of FTP.) Your heart rate should be sitting in mid to low Zone 2 heart rate, which is 70-80% of LTHR, up to 85% of LTHR, but not for long. It would be best if you held the highest comfortable cadence you can, for most this is 80-90rpm and your RPE should be a 2-4 on a scale of 1-10.

Sounds simple right? It's actually one of the harder sessions to get right because you spend most of the time questioning why you are riding so easy, and if this is really going to make you fitter and faster. You will have to trust us on that one! When you see this session in your Training Plan, follow these instructions! Or you might just pay for it when your next hard session comes around.

​

**Warm-Up**

prospects.name: Cadence Builds
prospects.description:
One of the best sessions for neuromuscular training, this drill asks you to progressively build from a cadence of 90 RPM to your MAX over 30 seconds, recover, and repeat several times. Cadence builds improve how you recruit your leg, gluteal, and core muscles throughout your pedal stroke by progressing to your maximal cadence. By reaching your highest cadence possible, you are training the 'on/off' switch in each muscle group to not only work faster but to have less overlap with your other muscle groups. This session trains your hamstring muscles to 'turn off' when your quads 'turn on' and vice-versa, resulting in a more efficient pedal stroke at both high and low cadences.

​

**LEARN MORE**

Listen to The Knowledge podcast, by Wahoo Sports Science - The Benefits of High Cadence Training: [https://wahoosystm.com/BenefitsofHighCadence](https://wahoosystm.com/BenefitsofHighCadence)

prospects.name: Strides & Drills
prospects.description:
This is a technique-focused session designed to develop your agility, stability, range of motion, and foot speed. There is no focus on heart rate zones so you may choose to leave your monitor at home for these sessions. Between sets of each drill, you should jog/walk easily to fully recover between the efforts. While these efforts shouldn’t be too taxing on you, the key is perfect form, so you want to be hitting each one rested enough that you can maintain great form for the duration. You should take a bit of extra rest between techniques, again to ensure you are rested and can nail the form. Before starting the workout, familiarize yourself with the format for high knees, butt kicks, skipping, carioca and strides. Find a flat track, field, or 50-100m of open space to perform this workout (football and soccer fields are great for this).

​

For help understanding your run workout and calculating your pace zones, please see [this article](https://wahoosystm.com/RunningSessionFAQ).

Learn how to perform your [**Running Drills**](https://support.wahoofitness.com/hc/en-us/articles/4404080091922-Running-Drills) here.

​

**Warm-up:**

Start off with 5-10 minutes of easy jogging/walking.

High Knees: 2-3 sets of 50m high knees.

Easy jog/walk for 30-60 seconds between.

- Take short strides, bringing your knees up high enough that your upper legs are parallel to the ground. Focus on achieving high knees AND quick turnover, or performing as many reps as possible in a short distance.

**Butt Kicks:**

2-3 sets of 50m butt kicks.

Easy jog/walk for 30-60 seconds between.

- This should actually look similar to a high knee drill, but with the heels coming up to touch the bottom of your butt. Take short strides while using your hamstrings to lift your heels up beneath your butt. Your knees should come up in front of your body while pulling your heels up beneath your hips, rather than keeping your quads and knees below and in line with your hips.

**Skipping:**

3-4 sets of 50m skipping.

Easy jog/walk for 30-60 seconds between.

- Focus on a high knee drive and swinging your arms at your sides like you would when running.

**Carioca:**

4 sets of 30m Carioca in each direction (8 total).

Rest for 20 seconds between direction changes (at your discretion).

- For this drill, you need to face sidewise to the direction you want to go. Start off moving to the right. Bring your left knee up and across your body and put your left foot in front of your right foot. Step your right foot to the right so it is parallel with your left leg again (at this point you should be positioned in the same direction and orientation that you were at the start. Next step your left leg behind your right leg, again so it lands on the right side of your right leg. Then bring your right leg back across your body, once again ending up in the starting position. Repeat this pattern for 25-30m.

**Strides:**

2-3 sets of 60m; Gradually build effort from RPE 3-8.

Easy jog/walk for 30-60 seconds between. These are comprised of a steady acceleration over 60-80m up to 5k pace. The goal is to increase speed after each step, so you are reaching maximum speed at the end of the 60-80m stretch. You want to focus on keeping your shoulders, neck, and jaw relaxed while maintaining strong knee drive, straight and compact arm swing, planting the feet beneath the hips, and fast turnover.

​

High Knees + Butt Kicks:

Finish these drills with one set each of 50m high knees and butt kicks.

​

**Cool-down:**

Walk or jog for 5 minutes to cool down.

In case you need to brush up on your running [drills](https://wahoosystm.com/RunningSessionFAQ)

prospects.name: Cadence Drills (Builds/Holds/Single Leg)
prospects.description:
This workout combines several technique driven intervals. These will improve your overall form and efficiency on the bike. The first two drills, Cadence Holds and Builds, are designed to improve the way you recruit your leg, glute and core muscles throughout your pedal stroke. They do this by forcing you to sustain a cadence just above 'comfortable' and by pushing you to your maximal cadence.

​

The last drill, Single Leg Efforts, ask you to unclip one leg and ride at a steady, single-legged effort. This forces you to pull up on the pedal instead of just pushing down and ensures maximal muscle awareness and engagement. This workout is best done while riding indoors on a trainer because even small variations in terrain can affect your ability to properly execute this workout. The majority of this workout is done in heart rate Z1/2 /// 50-75% of threshold /// RPE 2-5. You should keep the effort level below threshold (heart rate Z4, 100% of threshold, RPE 7-8) during the max cadence efforts.

​

WORKOUT GOALS:

- To improve stillness and stability at high cadences.
- To improve muscle fiber engagement for improved efficiency at all cadences.
- To increase maximum cadence.
- To make that pedal stroke as smooth as butter.

CADENCE TARGETS:

- Warm-up 80-90rpm
- Build: 90-150rpm
- Hold: 115rpm
- Single Leg: 85rpm

Listen to The Knowledge podcast, by Wahoo Sports Science - The Benefits of High Cadence Training: [https://wahoosystm.com/BenefitsofHighCadence](https://wahoosystm.com/BenefitsofHighCadence)

prospects.name: Tempo Cadence Build: 1 x 45
prospects.description:
While the single tempo effort you complete in this session is steady in terms of power, it is the specific cadence targets that set this session apart from other tempo workouts.

​

Even though an effort at 80% of FTP might seem "easy" the truth is your body is working at processing oxygen and metabolites at nearly the same rate when you are right at FTP. The difference is that the overall stress on your system when riding tempo is considerably less than riding at FTP. That means you can either have harder days before or after a tempo session (compared to a Threshold session) or you can increase the duration of those tempo efforts to make the overall training stimulus equal (or greater) than completing several repeats right at your FTP.

​

This tempo effort is divided into 3 segments of equal duration. While the power is the same across all segments, your target cadence starts and low and increases with each new segment from 60rpm, 80rpm and finally 90rpm. Starting with a long block of low cadence should fatigue your muscles from the start of your effort. As the effort builds and you create more fatigue, the increased cadence targets will place a greater demand on your cardiovascular system. That will, in some way, feel like a nice break given the load you have been putting on your muscular system. The cadence targets in the final segment will force your fatigued muscles to maintain good coordination as the faster cadence requires your muscles to switch "on" and "off" at a faster rate. Between the low rpm sections, and the high rpm work under fatigue, this tempo session not only helps train your FTP, but it has a training benefit to your neuromuscular system.

​

You can expect your Heart Rate to remain low for the power targets during the low cadence segment at the start. As the effort progresses and you reach the final 10 minutes of the high rpm segment your heart rate might go over Z3, which is not something to worry about. While this session appears "easy" at first glance, don't be surprised if your legs are feeling it the next day.

​

**Warm-Up**

20 minutes @ RPE 3 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <75%

1 minute @ RPE 7 -- 90% of FTP -- HR <90%

1 minute @ RPE 7.5 -- 100% of FTP -- HR <95%

1 minute @ RPE 8 -- 110% of FTP -- HR <100%

7 minutes @ RPE 3 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <75%

​

**Main Effort**

Number of Sets: 1

Rest Between Sets: N/A

Interval Repeats per Set: 1

**Interval**

**Extra Volume**

25 minutes @ RPE 3.5 -- 60% of FTP -- HR <85%

​

**Cool Down**

5 minutes @ RPE 1.5 -- <45% of FTP -- HR < 70%

prospects.name: Serbia Upside Down Ep. 4
prospects.description:
🎬 Film: Serbia. A small country in the Balkan Peninsula that hides some of the most beautiful natural wonders and unique cultural heritage in this part of the world. Yet it remains unknown to many. Only the alternative, curious and brave plan their journeys in this hidden gem. However, a small self-organized crew from Serbia and Germany set a mission to discover and reveal those stunning natural creations of Serbia. On a bicycle. In just five days, they traversed 450 kilometers across six mountains of Western Serbia, and climbed around 11,000 meters to film and produce what you are about to experience.

​

🚴 Workout: This is a great way to watch a compelling documentary while developing your baseline aerobic fitness. The intensity of this workout will vary mostly between 60-70% of FTP, with heart rate remaining entirely in zone 2. This session will add minimal fatigue to your system, while still giving your aerobic engine the workload it needs to continue progressing.

prospects.name: Split Brick Race Pace 90/60
prospects.description:
This cycling session is part of a bike-run brick and is meant to be paired with one of the "Split" Brick Running sessions.

Today's workout is a double brick, which means that after each of the bike sessions you will do a brick run. This gives you the opportunity to practice T2, so make sure to have your running gear set up beforehand. When you finish the first bike session, dismount, transition, and complete the first brick run (details can be found in each of the “split brick” run workout descriptions ). Upon finishing the run, take a few moments to eat and drink if necessary then hop back on the bike for the second set.

This workout is a great opportunity to practice a negative split pacing technique. Begin the first cycling session at 55% of FTP to get warmed up and gradually increase to 75%. Aim to hold 75% of FTP for the last 60-75 minutes.  On the second cycling set, begin at 70% and increase to 75% after about 15 minutes.

​

Since this is a race pace workout, it is a great time to practice your nutrition strategies prior to race day. Aim to consume 50-75g of carbohydrates per hour. Note that the maximum fuel your body can process in 60 minutes is 90 grams, but only if 60g comes from glucose and 30g from fructose. Unless you know the exact sugar breakdown of your nutrition do not aim for 90g per hour.

It is a good idea to weigh yourself before and after this session so you can determine if you are drinking enough. Losing 1-2 pounds of water weight during this session is okay, any more than that and you need to reassess your hydration plan.

​

**Warm-Up **(Only prior to first cycling session)

5 minutes @ RPE 2.5 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

**Main Effort**

Number of Sets: 2

Rest Between Sets: Your first Run session

**Interval**

Set 1: 90 minutes @ RPE 5 -- 70-75% of FTP -- HR <90% (Z3)

Set 2: 60 minutes @ RPE 5 -- 70-75% of FTP -- HR <90% (Z3)

Recovery: NA

**Extra Volume**

NA - Straight into Run 2!

prospects.name: Endurance  4
prospects.description:
The goal of this workout is to help develop your baseline aerobic fitness. While we are all about the High-Intensity Interval Training that most of our videos dish out, there are just times in a well-structured training plan that a proper Endurance/Base ride is just what your body needs.

This session will add minimal fatigue to your system, while still giving your aerobic engine the workload it needs to continue progressing. Steady Long Endurance rides are one of the best ways to cap off a long 2 or 3-week training block when your fatigue is high, your legs are tired, but you have just a bit more to squeeze out of yourself before you take your rest week, but only if you do it right!

​

Most people ride too hard when they head out for their "base miles." Truth be told, a proper Zone 2 ride should not leave you fatigued or your legs wasted. So what does a "proper" Zone 2 ride look like?

For 90% of the ride, you should stay between 55% and 65% of your FTP, at times going up to 70% is ok, but not over. (To spice things up, we have broken this session into 10-minute segments alternating from 60 to 65% of FTP.) Your heart rate should be sitting in mid to low Zone 2 heart rate, which is 70-80% of LTHR, up to 85% of LTHR, but not for long. It would be best if you held the highest comfortable cadence you can, for most this is 80-90rpm and your RPE should be a 2-4 on a scale of 1-10.

​

Sounds simple right? It's actually one of the harder sessions to get right because you spend most of the time questioning why you are riding so easy, and if this is really going to make you fitter and faster. You will have to trust us on that one! When you see this session in your Training Plan, follow these instructions! Or you might just pay for it when your next hard session comes around.

​

**Warm-Up**

5 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

**Main Effort**

Number of Sets: 11

Rest Between Sets: 10 minutes @ RPE 3.5 -- 60% of FTP -- HR <80%

Interval Repeats per Set: 1

**Interval**

10 minutes @ RPE 4 -- 65% of FTP -- HR <80%

​

**Extra Volume**

N/A

​

**Cool Down**

5 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

prospects.name: Provence: Luberon
prospects.description:
If those are the Luberon mountains, we must be in Provence, France. Starting in the village of Roussillon, today's ride takes you some stunning scenery -- if you're able to notice through the series of short(ish), but intense, intervals. To take your mind off the effort, Mike gives you a geology lesson, shows you how the local energy bars are made, tells a rather gruesome love story, walks you down some rather narrow village paths, and explains what a 'dog drowning boat' is.

[**Route on Strava**](https://www.strava.com/activities/3914666714)

_Your Host: There are few people who know the mountains and roads of Europe better than Wahoo Ambassador Michael Cotty. As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. As your On Location co-creator and host, Mike's engaging character, curious mind, and friendly nature will have you cueing up your next ride with him before you've even finished the cool-down._

prospects.name: Short Efforts: 30s/30s
prospects.description:
The short duration, high intensity of these intervals will help develop both your aerobic capacity and VO2 max. You should run these intervals fast, but they're not all out sprints because you only have 30 seconds to recover between each effort. If you start too fast you'll have to slow down on subsequent intervals, and the goal is to run them at the same pace or even get faster toward the end. Aim for mile pace or slightly faster and run on feel as best you can. Your heart rate is not a reliable way to gauge your effort because of the delay in response to intensity change.

This is a NoVid workout; if you have a treadmill, you can enjoy the guided workout as you would a cycling NoVid.

​

For help understanding your run workout and calculating your pace zones, please see [this article](https://wahoosystm.com/RunningSessionFAQ).

Learn how to perform your [**Running Drills**](https://support.wahoofitness.com/hc/en-us/articles/4404080091922-Running-Drills) here.

​

**Warm-up**

10 minutes @ RPE 2-4 -- 120-145% of RTP -- HR 70-87% (Z2)

​

**Activation 1: Drills of choice: butt kicks, high knees, etc.**

Number of Sets: 2

Rest Between Sets: 30 sec

Interval Distance: 50m

Activation 2: 150-200m Strides

Number of Sets: 2-3

Rest Between Sets: 30-60 seconds

Interval Effort: Build from 120-100% of RTP (Z4a)

​

**Main Effort**

Number of Sets: 1

Number of Repeats: 8

Interval Duration: 30 seconds

Rest Between repeats: 30 seconds

Interval Effort: RPE 8.5 --85% of RTP --HR 100-105% (Z5)

Recovery Effort: RPE 2 -- > 145% of RTP

\*Heart rate is not a useful metric for recovery effort during this workout because of the very short interval duration. Initially, it may, but by the end of the set, your HR will not decrease very much within the 30 second recovery window.

​

**Cool-down:**

Walk or jog for 5-10 minutes to cool down (Z1)

prospects.description:
This is an active recovery ride built with purpose. Low-intensity endurance work is paired with brief high-cadence neuromuscular activations to keep the nervous system awake without creating new fatigue. You’ll stay well below threshold throughout, allowing your body to absorb previous hard sessions and prepare for what’s ahead.

​

Set on the peaceful roads leading to the summit of Port de la Vall d’Ebo, this ride promotes circulation, technique, and mental reset. It’s ideal after race days or big training blocks — a smart session that helps you recover better, so you can train harder tomorrow. No ego, no watts chasing — just intentional recovery done right.

[**Wahoo Route**](https://www.strava.com/activities/13996505846)

prospects.name: Strides & Drills
prospects.description:
This is a technique-focused session designed to develop your agility, stability, range of motion, and foot speed. There is no focus on heart rate zones so you may choose to leave your monitor at home for these sessions. Between sets of each drill, you should jog/walk easily to fully recover between the efforts. While these efforts shouldn’t be too taxing on you, the key is perfect form, so you want to be hitting each one rested enough that you can maintain great form for the duration. You should take a bit of extra rest between techniques, again to ensure you are rested and can nail the form. Before starting the workout, familiarize yourself with the format for high knees, butt kicks, skipping, carioca and strides. Find a flat track, field, or 50-100m of open space to perform this workout (football and soccer fields are great for this).

​

For help understanding your run workout and calculating your pace zones, please see [this article](https://wahoosystm.com/RunningSessionFAQ).

Learn how to perform your [**Running Drills**](https://support.wahoofitness.com/hc/en-us/articles/4404080091922-Running-Drills) here.

​

**Warm-up:**

Start off with 5-10 minutes of easy jogging/walking.

High Knees: 2-3 sets of 50m high knees.

Easy jog/walk for 30-60 seconds between.

- Take short strides, bringing your knees up high enough that your upper legs are parallel to the ground. Focus on achieving high knees AND quick turnover, or performing as many reps as possible in a short distance.

**Butt Kicks:**

2-3 sets of 50m butt kicks.

Easy jog/walk for 30-60 seconds between.

- This should actually look similar to a high knee drill, but with the heels coming up to touch the bottom of your butt. Take short strides while using your hamstrings to lift your heels up beneath your butt. Your knees should come up in front of your body while pulling your heels up beneath your hips, rather than keeping your quads and knees below and in line with your hips.

**Skipping:**

3-4 sets of 50m skipping.

Easy jog/walk for 30-60 seconds between.

- Focus on a high knee drive and swinging your arms at your sides like you would when running.

**Carioca:**

4 sets of 30m Carioca in each direction (8 total).

Rest for 20 seconds between direction changes (at your discretion).

- For this drill, you need to face sidewise to the direction you want to go. Start off moving to the right. Bring your left knee up and across your body and put your left foot in front of your right foot. Step your right foot to the right so it is parallel with your left leg again (at this point you should be positioned in the same direction and orientation that you were at the start. Next step your left leg behind your right leg, again so it lands on the right side of your right leg. Then bring your right leg back across your body, once again ending up in the starting position. Repeat this pattern for 25-30m.

**Strides:**

2-3 sets of 60m; Gradually build effort from RPE 3-8.

Easy jog/walk for 30-60 seconds between. These are comprised of a steady acceleration over 60-80m up to 5k pace. The goal is to increase speed after each step, so you are reaching maximum speed at the end of the 60-80m stretch. You want to focus on keeping your shoulders, neck, and jaw relaxed while maintaining strong knee drive, straight and compact arm swing, planting the feet beneath the hips, and fast turnover.

​

High Knees + Butt Kicks:

Finish these drills with one set each of 50m high knees and butt kicks.

​

**Cool-down:**

Walk or jog for 5 minutes to cool down.

In case you need to brush up on your running [drills](https://wahoosystm.com/RunningSessionFAQ)

prospects.name: Tempo Build: 1 x 60
prospects.description:
Tempo sessions are always a great time to work on pace control, especially Tempo efforts longer than 30 minutes. We are taking that pacing demand a bit further in this session by forcing you to slightly increase your effort as time goes on. This is referred to as a "Negative-Split", meaning the second half is faster (or you hold a higher power) than the first half.

​

While you might question the benefit of doing "easier" tempo efforts, the truth is when riding between 80% and 100% of FTP your body processes oxygen and metabolites at nearly the same rate. Holding a higher power will give you a higher single day training stimulus, but looking at the big picture that can have its drawbacks. Mainly the fatigue those harder sessions cause, which requires easier workouts the days before and after. Sticking to the Tempo targets gets you nearly the same training stimulus while allowing you to hit harder sessions the rest of the week.

​

This session contains a single 60-minute tempo effort, broken into three 20-minute segments. You will spend the first 20-minutes at 80% of FTP, the next 20 at 84%, and the final 20 at 87%. By the time you hit the last 10-minutes of this effort, that 87% will feel much harder than it should. Another way of thinking about this one, if you were to reverse the order, and start at 87%, what you would likely find is that your RPE stays fairly consistent for the entire effort, even though the power targets are dropping.

​

Overheating, not drinking enough, being under-fueled and mental fatigue will all play a factor in how you feel in that final block. They will also impact your heart rate. While these power targets are usually associated with Zone 3 heart rate, many people will see their heart rate climb into low Z4 if they are not hydrating properly, or have inadequate cooling. This can be a great session to act as a "wake up call" on any poor training habits you might have so take note and aim to address those issues during your next workout.

​

**Warm Up**

30 minutes @ RPE 2.5 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70%

1 minute @ RPE 7 -- 95% of FTP -- HR <100%

1 minute @ RPE 7.5 -- 100% of FTP -- HR <100%

1 minute @ RPE 8 -- 105% of FTP -- HR <100%

7 minutes @ RPE 2.5 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

**Main Effort**

Number of sets: NA

Rest between sets: NA

Interval repeats per: NA

**Interval**

20 minutes @ RPE 6 -- 80% of FTP -- HR <100

20 minutes@ RPE 6.5 -- 84% of FTP -- HR <100%

20 minutes @ RPE 7 -- 87% of FTP -- HR <100%

​

**Extra Volume**

45 minutes @ RPE 3 -- 60% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

**Cool Down**

5 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

prospects.name: Endurance  1
prospects.description:
The goal of this workout is to help develop your baseline aerobic fitness. While we are all about the High-Intensity Interval Training that most of our videos dish out, there are times in a well-structured training plan that a proper Endurance/Base ride is just what your body needs.

​

This session will add minimal fatigue to your system, while still giving your aerobic engine the workload it needs to continue progressing. Steady Long Endurance rides are one of the best ways to cap off a long 2 or 3-week training block when your fatigue is high and your legs are tired, but you have just a bit more to squeeze out of yourself before you take your rest week. Shorter Endurance rides (like this one) can fit in both a hard week of training and a recovery week. That is, only if you do it right! Most people ride too hard when they head out for their "base miles."

​

Truth be told, a proper Zone 2 ride, especially one under 90 minutes should not leave you fatigued or your legs wasted.

So what does a "proper" Zone 2 ride look like? For 90% of the ride, you should stay between 55% and 65% of your FTP, at times going up to 70%, but not over. (To spice things up, we have broken this session into 10-minute segments alternating from 60 to 65% of FTP.) Your heart rate should be sitting in low to mid Zone 2 heart rate, which is 70-80% of LTHR up to 85% of LTHR, but not for long. It would be best if you held the highest comfortable cadence you can; for most this is 80-90rpm. Also, your RPE should be a 2-4 on a scale of 1-10.

​

Sounds simple right? It's actually one of the harder sessions to get right because you spend most of the time questioning why you are riding so easy, and if this is really going to make you fitter and faster, but you will have to trust us on this one! When you see this session in your Training Plan, follow these instructions, or you might just pay for it when your next hard session comes around.

​

**Warm Up**

5 minutes @ RPE 3 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

**Main Effort**

Number of Sets: 1

Rest Between Sets: 10 minutes @ RPE 3.5 -- 60% of FTP -- HR <80%

Interval Repeats Per Set: 2

**Interval**

10 minutes @ RPE 4 -- 65% of FTP -- HR <80%

​

**Extra Volume**

NA

​

**Cool Down**

5 minutes @ RPE 2.5 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

prospects.name: Tapers
prospects.description:
When it comes to "peaking", or performing at your absolute best on a given day, the key is nailing your Taper. The term "Taper" refers to how you train in the week or so before your target event to ensure you deliver your best performance. Generally, tapering means reducing your total training volume but continuing to hit some high-intensity efforts. While there are individual variations in the best way to taper, this session has been used by countless professionals leading into the biggest races of their lives -- athletes like World Champions Rohan Dennis and Flora Duffy.

​

With 3 sets of micro-intervals (40/20s, 30/30s, and 20/40s) you will hit your system with just enough intensity to keep your legs sharp and responsive, without adding any real fatigue. Outside of those 3 sets of micro-intervals, this session is purposefully short and easy. This is a preparation session, not a training session! After all, your event is just around the corner and all of the important training is behind you. Riding harder or longer today will do absolutely nothing to increase your fitness by event day; in fact, all that would do is increase your fatigue, which will only hurt your performance. Rather, this session makes sure your body is humming along and ready to perform on the big day.

prospects.name: Threshold Brick: 1 x 5
prospects.description:
This short brick run is ideal for triathletes who need to practice running at race pace right off the bike. Moving quickly from the bike to the run is great transition practice and getting the legs moving quickly up to race pace is an important pacing lesson for triathletes and duathletes of any level. This workout is concluded with 10 minutes at endurance pace to provide an aerobic endurance stimulus and cool down.

​

This is a NoVid workout; if you have a treadmill, play this workout in the app and enjoy the guided workout as you would a cycling NoVid! Just turn off or ignore the power targets or any others that don't pertain to running.

​

For help understanding your run workout and calculating your pace zones, please see [this article](https://wahoosystm.com/RunningSessionFAQ).

Learn how to perform your [**Running Drills**](https://support.wahoofitness.com/hc/en-us/articles/4404080091922-Running-Drills) here.

​

**Warm-Up**

Bike Session

​

**Main Effort**

Interval Duration: 5 mins

Interval Effort: 5 minutes @ RPE 6.5-7 --110-100% of RTP --HR 95-100%

Recovery: NA

​

**Extra Volume**

NA

​

**Cool Down**

10 min @ RPE 3-4 -- 145-120% of RTP -- HR 70-87% 5 min @ RPE < 2 -- > 145% of RTP -- HR < 70%

prospects.name: Openers
prospects.description:
Whether you have power testing, a group ride you want to smash, that event you have been training all winter for, or even just a fun route you want to have a great ride on, this is the perfect session to do the day before. The key to this session is just enough time right around threshold, with sufficient recovery between efforts and a handful of sprints to prime all of your systems for tomorrow's event.

​

**Warm-Up**

4 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <65%

1 minutes @ RPE 3 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70%

1 minute @ RPE 4 -- 65% of FTP -- HR <80%

1 minute @ RPE 5 -- 75% of FTP -- HR <85%

30 seconds @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <75%

30 seconds @ RPE 9 -- 90-95% of AC (130-190% of FTP)

4 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

**Main Effort**

Number of sets: 3, all unique

Rest Between Sets: 8 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <75%

**Set 1**

Interval Repeats per set: 1

Interval: Effort: 3 minutes at @ RPE 7 -- 90% of FTP --HR <95%

**Set 2**

Interval Repeats per set: 1

Interval: Effort: 2 minutes @ RPE 7.5 -- 100% of FTP -- HR <100%

**Set 3**

Interval Repeats per set: 3

Interval: Effort: 30 seconds @ RPE 9 -- 95% of MAP (110-130% of FTP)

Recovery: 90 seconds @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <75%

​

**Extra Volume**

N/A

​

**Cool Down**

6 minutes @ RPE 1.5 -- <45% of FTP

prospects.name: 03. Establishing the Goal Setting Habit
prospects.description:
**GOAL SETTING**

A clear plan of action is essential to any undertaking. Setting concrete, actionable goals will keep you motivated and on track; whether you’re eyeing the top podium step or the summit of the local climb. We will help assess where you are today, where you want to go, and identify the steps needed to get there.

​

In this module, you will enable consistent progress by creating a habit of identifying monthly and weekly goals, with weekly rewards for achieving those goals.

​

**GET THE WORKBOOK**

If you haven't yet, download the [Mental Training Workbook](https://drive.google.com/file/d/11VIC1ZmuIwDpmv9xdeUrZ6NJ_nZraqPv/view?usp=sharing).

It's a fillable PDF, but you can print it if you prefer to work from a hard copy.

​

​

​

​

​

​

prospects.name: 04. Getting Positive
prospects.description:
Thoughts matter. To accomplish big goals you need the ability to maintain a positive mindset, regardless of what life gives you. Here's an overview of the power of maintaining a positive mindset. We’ll introduce specific techniques that will help you identify negative thoughts, see obstacles as opportunities, and take a more positive path forward.

​

**GET THE WORKBOOK**

If you haven't yet, download the [Mental Training Workbook](https://drive.google.com/file/d/11VIC1ZmuIwDpmv9xdeUrZ6NJ_nZraqPv/view?usp=sharing).

It's a fillable PDF, but you can print it if you prefer to work from a hard copy.

prospects.name: 05. Remembering Why
prospects.description:
Focus is essential to high performance. Without it, you can become distracted, give in to self-doubt, and struggle to motivate yourself. Strengthen your willpower through a deep understanding of your key motivators and then develop a system to remind you of them on a daily basis.

​

**GET THE WORKBOOK**

If you haven't yet, download the [Mental Training Workbook](https://drive.google.com/file/d/11VIC1ZmuIwDpmv9xdeUrZ6NJ_nZraqPv/view?usp=sharing).

It's a fillable PDF, but you can print it if you prefer to work from a hard copy.

prospects.name: 06. Relaxing to Recover
prospects.description:
Here you will complete a full Progressive Muscle Relaxation session. It’s part guided meditation and part focus exercise. You should listen to this module at least once per week to get in tune with your body, release tension, and maximize recovery.

​

**GET THE WORKBOOK**

If you haven't yet, download the [Mental Training Workbook](https://drive.google.com/file/d/11VIC1ZmuIwDpmv9xdeUrZ6NJ_nZraqPv/view?usp=sharing).

It's a fillable PDF, but you can print it if you prefer to work from a hard copy.

prospects.name: 07. Positive Self-Talk
prospects.description:
Improve your confidence and performance through three types of positive self-talk: Motivational, Instructional, and Reward. Here, we’ll look at the subtle and not-so-subtle effects that words have on our attitude and performance. You’ll listen more closely to the way you talk to yourself so you can improve that internal dialogue and become your own biggest fan.

​

**GET THE WORKBOOK**

If you haven't yet, download the [Mental Training Workbook](https://drive.google.com/file/d/11VIC1ZmuIwDpmv9xdeUrZ6NJ_nZraqPv/view?usp=sharing).

It's a fillable PDF, but you can print it if you prefer to work from a hard copy.

​

**LEARN MORE**

Listen to '[The Power of Positive Mental Strategies](https://the-knowledge-by-wahoo-sports-science.simplecast.com/episodes/episode-29-how-to-use-positive-self-talk-to-get-through-tough-moments-on-a-ride-mental-strategies)' on The Knowledge Podcast by Wahoo Fitness.

prospects.name: 08. Improving Focus
prospects.description:
Develop an understanding of why focused concentration is so important to your performance. We will delve into what it means to be in “The Zone," look at the psychology and the physiology of peak performance, and what it takes to get there.

**GET THE WORKBOOK**

If you haven't yet, download the [Mental Training Workbook](https://drive.google.com/file/d/11VIC1ZmuIwDpmv9xdeUrZ6NJ_nZraqPv/view?usp=sharing).

It's a fillable PDF, but you can print it if you prefer to work from a hard copy.

prospects.name: 10. First Month Review & Improve
prospects.description:
You’ll look back at each of your weekly goals, as well as your overall goal for the month, to see how you did. This is your chance to give yourself a pat on the back, celebrate your successes, and identify how you’re going to do even better.

​

After looking to see what the past month can teach you, you’re going to turn your attention towards what lies ahead, setting new monthly and weekly goals.

​

**GET THE WORKBOOK**

If you haven't yet, download the [Mental Training Workbook](https://drive.google.com/file/d/11VIC1ZmuIwDpmv9xdeUrZ6NJ_nZraqPv/view?usp=sharing).

It's a fillable PDF, but you can print it if you prefer to work from a hard copy.

prospects.name: 11. The Successful Training Habit
prospects.description:
Let's zoom in on how you actually train, day in and day out. Great training sessions don’t just happen. You have to make a conscious effort, get everything together, then actually do the work. Successful athletes don’t leave their training to chance—they have a specific routine they go through **EVERY. SINGLE. TIME.** The more deliberate you are with your thoughts and actions before, during, and after your workouts, the better your training habit becomes and the greater your progress.

​

**GET THE WORKBOOK**

If you haven't yet, download the [Mental Training Workbook](https://drive.google.com/file/d/11VIC1ZmuIwDpmv9xdeUrZ6NJ_nZraqPv/view?usp=sharing).

It's a fillable PDF, but you can print it if you prefer to work from a hard copy.

prospects.name: 12. Workout Review
prospects.description:
We’re going to take the techniques you've learned during the “Monthly Review and Improve“ module, and apply them to your training sessions. This module should be completed immediately after finishing a workout. Have your workbook with you so after the cool-down you can start the workout review exercise immediately.

​

**GET THE WORKBOOK**

If you haven't yet, download the [Mental Training Workbook](https://drive.google.com/file/d/11VIC1ZmuIwDpmv9xdeUrZ6NJ_nZraqPv/view?usp=sharing).

It's a fillable PDF, but you can print it if you prefer to work from a hard copy.

prospects.description:
Pre-sleep visualization is a tool that helps build confidence and willpower. This module includes an exercise to detail what it will feel like to stand on the summit of your Big Mountain.

​

**GET THE WORKBOOK**

prospects.description:
Here you'll revisit the description of yourself that you wrote when first embarking on this journey. It is an opportunity to see how far you’ve come, but also a chance to look ahead.

​

**GET THE WORKBOOK**

If you haven't yet, download the [Mental Training Workbook](https://drive.google.com/file/d/11VIC1ZmuIwDpmv9xdeUrZ6NJ_nZraqPv/view?usp=sharing).

prospects.description:
This visualization exercise is designed to be completed when you’re in bed, ready to fall asleep. You’ll travel from your bedroom to the summit of your Big Mountain.

prospects.name: 16. Regular Monthly Review
prospects.description:
This process mirrors what you did in week five. If you feel like you’re making gains, it’s likely you’ve been getting the work in. If you’re not progressing—if you feel run down—look to see if there are any patterns.

**GET THE WORKBOOK**

If you haven't yet, download the [Mental Training Workbook](https://drive.google.com/file/d/11VIC1ZmuIwDpmv9xdeUrZ6NJ_nZraqPv/view?usp=sharing).

It's a fillable PDF, but you can print it if you prefer to work from a hard copy.

prospects.name: 17. Overcoming Obstacles
prospects.description:
Rainbows? Puppy dogs? Not always. Sometimes things go wrong and this session will get you moving again. As a visualization exercise, this module is meant to be listened to whenever you feel stuck—whether that’s due to an obstacle you can’t see a way around, an injury, a loss of motivation, or any other reason which makes you doubt yourself. Even if you don’t have an obstacle right now, it’s a good idea to go through the module so you know what it’s about and when to use it. It will help you re-focus, reset, and reestablish your confidence in who you are and where you’re headed.

​

**GET THE WORKBOOK**

prospects.name: 05. Remembering Why
prospects.description:
Focus is essential to high performance. Without it, you can become distracted, give in to self-doubt, and struggle to motivate yourself. Strengthen your willpower through a deep understanding of your key motivators and then develop a system to remind you of them on a daily basis.

​

**GET THE WORKBOOK**

If you haven't yet, download the [Mental Training Workbook](https://drive.google.com/file/d/11VIC1ZmuIwDpmv9xdeUrZ6NJ_nZraqPv/view?usp=sharing).

It's a fillable PDF, but you can print it if you prefer to work from a hard copy.

prospects.name: 06. Relaxing to Recover
prospects.description:
Here you will complete a full Progressive Muscle Relaxation session. It’s part guided meditation and part focus exercise. You should listen to this module at least once per week to get in tune with your body, release tension, and maximize recovery.

​

**GET THE WORKBOOK**

If you haven't yet, download the [Mental Training Workbook](https://drive.google.com/file/d/11VIC1ZmuIwDpmv9xdeUrZ6NJ_nZraqPv/view?usp=sharing).

It's a fillable PDF, but you can print it if you prefer to work from a hard copy.

prospects.name: 18. Setting Event Goals
prospects.description:
Get clear on what an event really means to you and what your event-specific goals are.

​

"If you are going to win any battle, you have to do one thing: you have to make the mind run the body."

~ George S. Patton

**GET THE WORKBOOK**

If you haven't yet, download the [Mental Training Workbook](https://drive.google.com/file/d/11VIC1ZmuIwDpmv9xdeUrZ6NJ_nZraqPv/view?usp=sharing).

It's a fillable PDF, but you can print it if you prefer to work from a hard copy.

prospects.name: 19. Planning For Every Event Scenario
prospects.description:
Show up prepared by identifying things that could happen during the course of the event and how to deal with them.

**GET THE WORKBOOK**

If you haven't yet, download the [Mental Training Workbook](https://drive.google.com/file/d/11VIC1ZmuIwDpmv9xdeUrZ6NJ_nZraqPv/view?usp=sharing).

It's a fillable PDF, but you can print it if you prefer to work from a hard copy.

prospects.name: 20. Preparing To Crush It
prospects.description:
This pre-event visualization exercise will help you get in the zone to deliver what athletes and sports psychologists call a “peak performance;” it’s when everything flows and operates at the highest level almost without any effort.

​

**GET THE WORKBOOK**

If you haven't yet, download the [Mental Training Workbook](https://drive.google.com/file/d/11VIC1ZmuIwDpmv9xdeUrZ6NJ_nZraqPv/view?usp=sharing).

It's a fillable PDF, but you can print it if you prefer to work from a hard copy.

prospects.name: 21. How Did it Go?
prospects.description:
Once the dust has settled and your heart rate has returned to normal levels, listen to this module. It's meant to be completed 15 minutes after the event ends. Part two of this exercise is completed the next day when you’ve had time to process and reflect on everything that happened during the event day.

​

**GET THE WORKBOOK**

If you haven't yet, download the [Mental Training Workbook](https://drive.google.com/file/d/11VIC1ZmuIwDpmv9xdeUrZ6NJ_nZraqPv/view?usp=sharing).

It's a fillable PDF, but you can print it if you prefer to work from a hard copy.

prospects.name: 02. Identifying Your Personal Big Mountain
prospects.description:
What - exactly - are you trying to accomplish? When you're ready to answer that question, this module will help you gain clarity on who you are as an athlete and identify your major goal—your Personal Big Mountain.

​

**GET THE WORKBOOK**

If you haven't yet, download the [Mental Training Workbook](https://drive.google.com/file/d/11VIC1ZmuIwDpmv9xdeUrZ6NJ_nZraqPv/view?usp=sharing).

It's a fillable PDF, but you can print it if you prefer to work from a hard copy.

​

**LEARN MORE**

Listen to '[The Importance of SMART Goal Setting](https://the-knowledge-by-wahoo-sports-science.simplecast.com/episodes/start-now-goal-setting-basics)' and '[How to use your personal outlook to set more effective goals](https://the-knowledge-by-wahoo-sports-science.simplecast.com/episodes/know-thyself-how-to-use-your-personal-outlook-to-set-more-effective-goals)' on The Knowledge Podcast by Wahoo Sports Science.

prospects.name: 09. Focus Exercise
prospects.description:
Improve your ability to push away distractions and focus on the task at hand. This five-minute exercise will get you primed and ready to unleash your power from within. That means you should be in your kit and ready to train as soon as you complete this exercise.

​

**GET THE WORKBOOK**

If you haven't yet, download the [Mental Training Workbook](https://drive.google.com/file/d/11VIC1ZmuIwDpmv9xdeUrZ6NJ_nZraqPv/view?usp=sharing).

It's a fillable PDF, but you can print it if you prefer to work from a hard copy.

prospects.name: 15. Kicking Ass in your Sleep Part II
prospects.description:
This visualization exercise is designed to be completed when you’re in bed, ready to fall asleep. You’ll travel from your bedroom to the summit of your Big Mountain.

**GET THE WORKBOOK**

If you haven't yet, download the [Mental Training Workbook](https://drive.google.com/file/d/11VIC1ZmuIwDpmv9xdeUrZ6NJ_nZraqPv/view?usp=sharing).

It's a fillable PDF, but you can print it if you prefer to work from a hard copy.

prospects.name: 16. Regular Monthly Review
prospects.description:
This process mirrors what you did in week five. If you feel like you’re making gains, it’s likely you’ve been getting the work in. If you’re not progressing—if you feel run down—look to see if there are any patterns.

**GET THE WORKBOOK**

If you haven't yet, download the [Mental Training Workbook](https://drive.google.com/file/d/11VIC1ZmuIwDpmv9xdeUrZ6NJ_nZraqPv/view?usp=sharing).

It's a fillable PDF, but you can print it if you prefer to work from a hard copy.

prospects.name: 08. Improving Focus
prospects.description:
Develop an understanding of why focused concentration is so important to your performance. We will delve into what it means to be in “The Zone," look at the psychology and the physiology of peak performance, and what it takes to get there.

**GET THE WORKBOOK**

If you haven't yet, download the [Mental Training Workbook](https://drive.google.com/file/d/11VIC1ZmuIwDpmv9xdeUrZ6NJ_nZraqPv/view?usp=sharing).

prospects.name: 17. Overcoming Obstacles
prospects.description:
Rainbows? Puppy dogs? Not always. Sometimes things go wrong and this session will get you moving again. As a visualization exercise, this module is meant to be listened to whenever you feel stuck—whether that’s due to an obstacle you can’t see a way around, an injury, a loss of motivation, or any other reason which makes you doubt yourself. Even if you don’t have an obstacle right now, it’s a good idea to go through the module so you know what it’s about and when to use it. It will help you re-focus, reset, and reestablish your confidence in who you are and where you’re headed.

​

**GET THE WORKBOOK**

If you haven't yet, download the [Mental Training Workbook](https://drive.google.com/file/d/11VIC1ZmuIwDpmv9xdeUrZ6NJ_nZraqPv/view?usp=sharing).

It's a fillable PDF, but you can print it if you prefer to work from a hard copy.

prospects.name: Basic Yoga Poses
prospects.description: Throughout the SYSTM yoga program there are several basic, foundational moves that form the core of the routines. This session takes you through those moves in detail so you can master them and their more difficult variations.

prospects.name: Super Easy Stretch Routine I
prospects.description: Are you looking for a simple stretching routine you can do on a regular basis? New to yoga? Designed for yoga beginners, this gentle yoga session will get you on the road to a more flexible you. You've said for years you'd start stretching. Now's your chance.

prospects.name: Foot and Ankle Mobility for Runners
prospects.description: In this restorative sequence, we mobilize the toes, feet, and ankles; stretch the calves and hamstrings, and open up the hips. We start with a simple foot massage to bring movement into every part of your foot, from your toes up to your heel. With this extra range of motion, we then move into some gentle, dynamic stretches for the calves, hamstrings, and hips.

prospects.name: Total Newbie Yoga
prospects.description: Yoga-curious but don't know where to start? This session is a great place to dip your toes in. This easy, basic routine will introduce you to some simple foundational moves while giving you a little stretch and some light strength work at the same time. Think of it as the gateway drug to bringing yoga into your life.

prospects.name: Supple Spine & Hips
prospects.description:
This classic yoga sequence enhances mobility in the spine and hips while stretching the calves, hamstrings, hip flexors, and lower back. As you become familiar with the routine, you can begin to focus on synchronizing your breath with your movements, aiming to use nasal breathing as much as possible. It is an excellent practice for the morning to warm up and improve focus, or it can be done directly after a workout to help prevent extreme muscle stiffness.

​

The objectives are to improve mobility in the spine and hips, stretch the calves, hamstrings, hip flexors, and lower back, practice synchronizing breath and movement, and potentially alleviate lower back pain.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Mountain
- Half Sun Salutations
- Downward Dog
- Crescent Lunge
- Bridge
- Reclining Spinal Twist
- Final Resting Pose

prospects.name: Morning Yoga Routine
prospects.description: In this sequence, we start with a short breathing exercise to relax the body and calm the mind, then mobilize joints throughout the body. From there we move into deeper stretches for the hips and hamstrings and finish with a short meditation.

prospects.name: Stretch Out Your Legs
prospects.description:
This cool-down stretch is designed to release tension in the legs and hips, targeting the glutes, piriformis, calves, hamstrings, groin, quads, TFL, and lower back. It's an ideal routine for athletes to practice directly after a workout or in the evening before bed.

​

The objectives include stretching the glutes, piriformis, hamstrings, calves, groin, quads, and TFL, releasing tension in the lower back, and helping the body transition into the parasympathetic "rest or digest" mode after exercise, potentially alleviating lower back pain.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Dead Pigeon
- Reclining Hand-To-Big-Toe
- Reclining Groin Stretch
- Reclining Quad Stretch
- Reclining Spinal Twist (Eagle Variation)

prospects.name: Post-Workout Cool-Down
prospects.description: This gentle cool-down is designed to completely unwind you after your ride…and potentially send you to sleep. We move systematically through the body, loosening up and stretching out tight muscles. Try to stay relaxed throughout while breathing in and out through your nose.

prospects.name: Neck and Upper Back Recovery
prospects.description: In this Beginner sequence, we improve mobility in the neck, shoulders, upper and mid-back, open up the chest and shoulders and relieve tension at the lower back to help alleviate neck, shoulder, and interscapular pain. You can practice it in the morning or the evening.

prospects.name: Mobilize Your Body
prospects.description:
In this video, we focus on mobilizing the wrists, elbows, shoulders, neck, spine, hips, ankles, and toes to enhance overall mobility throughout the body. It is an excellent routine to practice in the morning or evening to alleviate stiffness.

​

The objectives are to increase mobility in the wrists, elbows, shoulders, neck, spine, hips, and ankles.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Screaming Toe
- Wrist Circles
- Elbow Circles
- Shoulder Circles
- Neck Circles
- Thunderbolt
- Kneeling Cat-Cow
- Thoracic Spine Circles
- Seated Twists
- Hip Circles
- Squat Twists
- Standing Forward Bends
- Reclining Hip Circles
- Windscreen Wipers
- Ankle Mobilisations
- Knees-To-Chest

prospects.name: Foot & Ankle Recovery
prospects.description:
In this restorative sequence, the focus is on mobilizing the toes, feet, and ankles, stretching the calves and hamstrings, and opening up the hips. The session begins with a calming breathing technique, followed by a simple foot massage to introduce movement from the toes up to the heel. With increased range of motion, the routine progresses to gentle, dynamic stretches for the calves, hamstrings, and hips. Since feet are often neglected and subjected to high demands from activities like running or cycling, practicing this sequence at least once a week helps to rebalance and address this issue.

​

The objectives are to improve mobility in the feet and ankles, stretch the calves and hamstrings, and open up the hips.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Easy Seat
- Box Breathing
- Foot Massage
- Downward Dog
- Screaming Toe
- Yoga Squat
- Ankle Stretch
- Ankle Mobilisations
- Windscreen Wipers

prospects.name: Improving Posture
prospects.description: Most cyclists suffer from rounded shoulders and a curved spine as a result of hours spent in the riding position. This series will release tension in your upper back and get you standing up straight and powerful again.

prospects.name: Breathing More Deeply
prospects.description: Diaphragmatic Breathing is a calming exercise that encourages you to breathe deeply into your abdomen. This can help improve your ability to take in oxygen on the bike, as well as help you stay calm on focused when the pressure is on.

prospects.name: Hip Mobility Flow for Runners I
prospects.description: This flow sequence focuses on improving mobility in the hips. It’s the perfect active recovery routine to practice on your day off, energize you first thing in the morning, or flow-through before your run. To get the most out of this session, try to synchronize your breathing and movement while breathing in and out through your nose.

prospects.name: Hip Flexor and Groin Recovery
prospects.description: In this Beginner sequence, we release the hip flexors and groin and stretch the hamstrings and calves. It's a great session to do after a workout or in the evening to prevent and alleviate lower back pain.

prospects.name: Spinal Flexibility
prospects.description:
This classic yoga sequence focuses on enhancing spinal flexibility by moving the spine through flexion, extension, rotation, and lateral flexion. It targets the shoulders, lats, obliques, lower back, quads, and glutes. This routine is excellent for increasing range of motion and reducing stiffness throughout the body. It can be practiced in the morning to help wake up or directly after a workout to prevent pain and stiffness.

​

The objectives are to increase spine and shoulder mobility, stretch the shoulders, lats, obliques, lower back, quads, and glutes, and reduce overall stiffness.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Mountain
- Sun Salutation
- Standing Sidebends
- Cat–Cow
- One-Handed Tiger
- Puppy + Twisted Puppy
- Seated Spinal Twist
- Final Resting Pose

prospects.name: Hamstring & Hip Release
prospects.description:
This hip-opening sequence is particularly effective for stretching the calves, hamstrings, groin, hip flexors, and quads. It's ideal for practicing after a workout or in the evening to increase flexibility and loosen up the hips.

​

The objectives are to stretch the calves, hamstrings, groin, hip flexors, and quads; open up the hips; and trigger a parasympathetic nervous system response.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Child’s Pose
- Downward Dog
- Runners Lunge
- Side Lunge
- Lizard
- Frog
- Hip Circles
- Reclining Quad Stretch
- Reclining Hand-To-Big-Toe 1 + 2
- Knees-To-Chest

prospects.name: Hips and Hamstrings
prospects.description: This routine is designed to open up the hips—the hip flexors, rotators, and glutes—and stretch the hamstrings. The session guides you through a series of lunges and finishes with Lizard and Pigeon pose. You can practice it in the morning, before or after a ride. Experiment to see what works best for you.

prospects.name: Lower Back Recovery
prospects.description: In this Beginner sequence, we release tension in the hips—the groin, glutes, piriformis, TFL, and external hip rotators, stretch the calves and hamstrings and re-align the pelvis. It's a great session to practice in the morning or the evening to prevent and alleviate lower back pain.

prospects.name: Thoracic Recovery
prospects.description: In this Beginner sequence, we improve thoracic and shoulder mobility, open up the chest and stretch the lats, shoulders, triceps, calves, and hamstrings to improve posture, facilitate better breathing and help to alleviate upper back, interscapular, and neck pain. You can practice it in the morning or the evening.

prospects.name: Guided Meditation
prospects.description: This is a short guided meditation that focuses on your breath and the sensations in your body. Clearing your mind through meditation can help you increase your focus, which is an important skill when you're riding on the limit.

prospects.name: Lower Back Release
prospects.description:
This video is designed to alleviate tightness in the lower back by releasing tension in the lower back, glutes, piriformis, groin, hamstrings, and calves through a series of reclining hip-opening poses combined with deep, diaphragmatic breathing.

​

The objectives are to stretch the lower back, glutes, piriformis, groin, hamstrings, and calves, improve mobility in the hips and spine, and help alleviate lower back pain.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Wind-Relieving
- Reclining Spinal Twist
- Knees-To-Chest
- Reclining Hand-To-Big-Toe
- Dead Pigeon
- Happy Baby

prospects.name: Chest Opener
prospects.description:
This sequence is designed to open up the chest and improve mobility in the spine and shoulders. It includes stretches for the forearms, shoulders, chest, hip flexors, hamstrings, and calves. The poses are particularly effective for alleviating pain between the shoulder blades. This sequence is ideal as a post-workout routine, especially after working the chest or engaging in activities that involve a closed-chest posture. It is also beneficial after a day spent hunched over a computer.

​

The objectives are to open up the chest, enhance mobility in the spine and shoulders, stretch the forearms, shoulders, chest, hip flexors, calves, and hamstrings, and help alleviate pain between the shoulders.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Cat–Cow with Forearm Stretch
- Puppy
- Half-Twisted Scorpion
- Downward Dog
- Low Lunge with Chest Opener
- Kneeling Cat-Cow
- Camel
- Wide-Knee Child’s Pose
- Reclining Butterfly (on blocks)

prospects.name: Total Hip Therapy for Runners
prospects.description: This therapeutic session stretches the hip muscles in all directions to ease pain and stiffness in the pelvis and lower back.  It’s a great one to practice after your run or before bed to ensure that you wake up feeling supple and pain-free.

prospects.name: Hamstrings and TFL for Runners
prospects.description: This therapeutic session is designed to strengthen and stretch the back of your thighs and outside hips to improve mobility and ensure proper function. It can help to alleviate lower back pain and can be practiced in the morning, evening, or directly after training.

prospects.name: Body Scan
prospects.description:
This body scan meditation is designed to transition the body from the sympathetic to the parasympathetic nervous system response. It can be practiced directly after a workout as a cool-down or before bed to facilitate deep, restorative sleep.

​

The objectives are to calm the central nervous system, transition the body into parasympathetic "rest or digest" mode after exercise, improve focus, and relieve stress.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Final Resting Pose

prospects.name: Hamstring and Calf Flexibility
prospects.description: Cyclists are notorious for poor hamstring and calf flexibility. But these muscles can only be properly engaged when they're flexible. This series will increase your range of motion, boosting performance while helping you avoid injury.

prospects.name: Super Easy Stretch Routine I
prospects.description: Are you looking for a simple stretching routine you can do on a regular basis? New to yoga? Designed for yoga beginners, this gentle yoga session will get you on the road to a more flexible you. You've said for years you'd start stretching. Now's your chance.

prospects.name: Recovery Booster
prospects.description: It may seem counterintuitive, but it's during recovery when you actually get stronger and consolidate the gains you've made while training. Without proper recovery, you won't improve. This session helps boost your recovery time, relaxing you and ensuring you give your body the chance to grow stronger.

prospects.name: Post-Run Stretch
prospects.description: This sequence is designed to keep you strong, supple, and always in the game. It’s a simple and easy series of poses that slowly and carefully allows you to release tension in the primary muscles of the lower body, including the calves, hamstrings, hip flexors, glutes, piriformis, and lower back.

prospects.name: Loosen Neck and Shoulders
prospects.description: Cycling can put a lot of strain on your neck and shoulders, especially if you spend a lot of time down in the drops or in an aero position. This session will help loosen your neck and shoulders with a series of exercises that will release tension and have you feeling relaxed and ready to hit it again.

prospects.name: Lower Back Recovery
prospects.description: In this Beginner sequence, we release tension in the hips—the groin, glutes, piriformis, TFL, and external hip rotators, stretch the calves and hamstrings and re-align the pelvis. It's a great session to practice in the morning or the evening to prevent and alleviate lower back pain.

prospects.name: Hip Flexor and Groin Recovery
prospects.description: In this Beginner sequence, we release the hip flexors and groin and stretch the hamstrings and calves. It's a great session to do after a workout or in the evening to prevent and alleviate lower back pain.

prospects.name: Basic Yoga Poses
prospects.description: Throughout the SYSTM yoga program there are several basic, foundational moves that form the core of the routines. This session takes you through those moves in detail so you can master them and their more difficult variations.

prospects.name: Breathing to Calm Down I
prospects.description: 3-Part Breath is a therapeutic breathing technique that encourages you to use your full lung capacity. This can help improve your ability to take in oxygen on the bike, as well as help you stay calm on focused when the pressure is on.

prospects.name: Balance Training for Runners
prospects.description: Balance training is crucial to improve your running performance, and yoga is a fantastic way to hone your skills. In this sequence, we practice a number of one-legged standing, dynamic poses to improve your balance and proprioception (your sense of where your body is in space). These poses are also great for building strength and flexibility in the hips.

prospects.name: Breathing to Calm Down II
prospects.description: In 4-7-8 Breath your exhalations are twice as long as your inhalations. It's a therapeutic breathing technique that can help to reduce discomfort and calm your nervous system, especially when you're under pressure.

prospects.name: Pre-Ride Warm-Up
prospects.description:
This sequence is designed to activate your posterior chain—the calves, hamstrings, glutes, lower, upper, and mid-back, as well as your core—the abs and obliques. It’s crucial that you engage these muscles before every ride to give you maximum power, speed, and endurance on the bike.

​

Listen to why warm-ups are so important in this episode of The Knowledge podcast by Wahoo Sports Science:

[https://wahoosystm.com/WarmingupTheEngine](https://wahoosystm.com/WarmingupTheEngine)

prospects.name: Full Body Mobility
prospects.description: This sequence is designed to improve the range of motion throughout the body, focusing on the spine, shoulders, and hips. It combines twists, side bends, and balance poses to enhance total body flexibility and agility.

prospects.name: Basic Yoga Poses
prospects.description: Throughout the SYSTM yoga program there are several basic, foundational moves that form the core of the routines. This session takes you through those moves in detail so you can master them and their more difficult variations.

prospects.name: Hip Mobility Flow for Runners I
prospects.description: This flow sequence focuses on improving mobility in the hips. It’s the perfect active recovery routine to practice on your day off, energize you first thing in the morning, or flow-through before your run. To get the most out of this session, try to synchronize your breathing and movement while breathing in and out through your nose.

prospects.name: Yoga for Travel
prospects.description: If you're traveling and will be off your bike for some time, you might feel that all is lost. But we've created a routine for travelers to keep you balanced, loose, and strong. Do this daily while on the road so you'll be in top condition when you can get back home.

You can practice it in the morning or the evening.

prospects.name: Super Easy Stretch Routine II
prospects.description: You've just finished a difficult training session. You probably just want to curl up in a ball, but to make sure your body stays limber and flexible this sequence will stretch you out and open you up. You'll be ready to hit it again in no time.

prospects.name: Mobilize and Activate
prospects.description: Get out of your habitual movement patterns and get ready to take on the day with this activation session. You'll flow through a series of standing yoga poses to simultaneously challenge your strength, flexibility, and range of motion, leaving you feeling energized.

prospects.name: Chest Opener
prospects.description:
This sequence is designed to open up the chest and improve mobility in the spine and shoulders. It includes stretches for the forearms, shoulders, chest, hip flexors, hamstrings, and calves. This sequence is ideal as a post-workout routine, especially after working the chest or engaging in activities that involve a closed-chest posture. It is also beneficial after a day spent hunched over a computer.

​

The objectives are to open up the chest, enhance mobility in the spine and shoulders, stretch the forearms, shoulders, chest, hip flexors, calves, and hamstrings, and help alleviate pain between the shoulders.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Half-Twisted Scorpion
- Downward Dog
- Low Lunge with Chest Opener
- Kneeling Cat-Cow
- Camel
- Wide-Knee Child’s Pose
- Reclining Butterfly (on blocks)

prospects.name: The One For Your Hips
prospects.description:
This classic yoga sequence is designed to enhance hip mobility by stretching the hip flexors, glutes, groin, hamstrings, and calves through a series of static poses. The routine emphasizes releasing tension with each exhalation. It is particularly effective for alleviating lower back pain and improving hip range of motion. This sequence can be practiced at any time of day.

​

The objectives are to improve hip mobility, stretch the hip flexors, glutes, groin, hamstrings, and calves, practice nasal breathing with movement, and potentially alleviate lower back pain.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Mountain
- Low Lunge
- Downward Dog Split
- Lizard
- Pigeon

prospects.description: In this Beginner / Intermediate sequence, we stabilize the muscles that support your shoulder blades, activate the posterior chain, strengthen the core and stretch the chest and fronts of the shoulders. This helps reduce your risk of neck and shoulder injury, alleviate neck and interscapular pain, and improve your posture. It's a great session to do in the morning or before a workout.

prospects.name: Mobilize Your Body
prospects.description:
In this video, we focus on mobilizing the wrists, elbows, shoulders, neck, spine, hips, ankles, and toes to enhance overall mobility throughout the body. It is an excellent routine to practice in the morning or evening to alleviate stiffness.

​

The objectives are to increase mobility in the wrists, elbows, shoulders, neck, spine, hips, and ankles.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Screaming Toe
- Wrist Circles
- Elbow Circles
- Shoulder Circles
- Neck Circles
- Thunderbolt
- Kneeling Cat-Cow
- Thoracic Spine Circles
- Seated Twists
- Hip Circles
- Squat Twists
- Standing Forward Bends
- Reclining Hip Circles
- Windscreen Wipers
- Ankle Mobilisations
- Knees-To-Chest

prospects.name: Breathing More Deeply
prospects.description: Diaphragmatic Breathing is a calming exercise that encourages you to breathe deeply into your abdomen. This can help improve your ability to take in oxygen on the bike, as well as help you stay calm on focused when the pressure is on.

prospects.name: Improving Posture
prospects.description: Most cyclists suffer from rounded shoulders and a curved spine as a result of hours spent in the riding position. This series will release tension in your upper back and get you standing up straight and powerful again.

prospects.name: Lower Back Release
prospects.description:
This video is designed to alleviate tightness in the lower back by releasing tension in the lower back, glutes, piriformis, groin, hamstrings, and calves through a series of reclining hip-opening poses combined with deep, diaphragmatic breathing.

​

The objectives are to stretch the lower back, glutes, piriformis, groin, hamstrings, and calves, improve mobility in the hips and spine, and help alleviate lower back pain.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Wind-Relieving
- Reclining Spinal Twist
- Knees-To-Chest
- Reclining Hand-To-Big-Toe
- Dead Pigeon
- Happy Baby

prospects.name: Balance and Core Control for Runners
prospects.description: This sequence is designed to improve your balance and core control, indispensable skills for all runners. We strengthen the abs, obliques, and hips, with a focus on moving slowly with control, dynamically between the postures.

prospects.name: Total Leg Strength
prospects.description:
This sequence is designed to strengthen the legs, including the glutes, quads, hamstrings, calves, shins, ankles, and feet, while also improving mobility in the hips, spine, and shoulders. It provides a good stretch for the quads, hamstrings, and calves, making it ideal for activating the leg muscles in the morning or before a workout.

​

The objectives are to strengthen the glutes, quads, hamstrings, calves, shins, ankles, and feet; stretch the quads, hamstrings, and calves; and improve hip, spine, and shoulder mobility.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Mountain
- Half Sun Salutations
- Chair + Chair Twist
- Runners Lunge
- High Lunge
- Silver Surfer
- Downward Dog
- Half-Reclining Hero
- Final Resting Pose

prospects.name: Hip and Pelvis Stability
prospects.description: In this Intermediate sequence, we strengthen the hips through their full range of motion and stabilize the pelvis to improve balance and reduce your risk of knee, IT band, and lower back injury. It's a great session to do in the morning or before a workout.

prospects.name: Post-Run Stretch
prospects.description: This sequence is designed to keep you strong, supple, and always in the game. It’s a simple and easy series of poses that slowly and carefully allows you to release tension in the primary muscles of the lower body, including the calves, hamstrings, hip flexors, glutes, piriformis, and lower back.

prospects.name: Spinal Flexibility
prospects.description:
This classic yoga sequence focuses on enhancing spinal flexibility by moving the spine through flexion, extension, rotation, and lateral flexion. It targets the shoulders, lats, obliques, lower back, quads, and glutes. This routine is excellent for increasing range of motion and reducing stiffness throughout the body. It can be practiced in the morning to help wake up or directly after a workout to prevent pain and stiffness.

​

The objectives are to increase spine and shoulder mobility, stretch the shoulders, lats, obliques, lower back, quads, and glutes, and reduce overall stiffness.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Mountain
- Sun Salutation
- Standing Sidebends
- Cat–Cow
- One-Handed Tiger
- Puppy + Twisted Puppy
- Seated Spinal Twist
- Final Resting Pose

prospects.name: Core Stability
prospects.description: In this Intermediate sequence, we stabilize the spine, ribs and pelvis; strengthen the deep abdominals, obliques and lower back; and activate the glutes to improve balance, help to prevent and alleviate lower back pain and enhance athletic performance. It's a great session to do in the morning or pre-workout.

prospects.name: Stretch Out Your Legs
prospects.description:
This cool-down stretch is designed to release tension in the legs and hips, targeting the glutes, piriformis, calves, hamstrings, groin, quads, TFL, and lower back. It's an ideal routine for athletes to practice directly after a workout or in the evening before bed.

​

The objectives include stretching the glutes, piriformis, hamstrings, calves, groin, quads, and TFL, releasing tension in the lower back, and helping the body transition into the parasympathetic "rest or digest" mode after exercise, potentially alleviating lower back pain.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Dead Pigeon
- Reclining Hand-To-Big-Toe
- Reclining Groin Stretch
- Reclining Quad Stretch
- Reclining Spinal Twist (Eagle Variation)

prospects.name: Classic Yoga Flow
prospects.description:
This classic, hip-focused sequence enhances mobility in the spine and hips while stretching the calves, hamstrings, hip flexors, and groin, and strengthening the quads and hips. As you become familiar with the routine, you can work on synchronizing your breath with your movements, aiming to breathe in and out through your nose throughout. It is an excellent practice for the morning to sharpen your focus or directly after a workout to help prevent muscle stiffness.

​

The objectives are to improve mobility in the spine and hips, strengthen the hips and quads, stretch the calves, hamstrings, hip flexors, and groin, and practice synchronizing breath and movement.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Mountain
- High Lunge (+ Twist)
- Downward Dog
- Warrior 2
- Triangle
- Squat
- Final Resting Pose

prospects.name: Upper Body Strength
prospects.description: Those things you use to type and lift up your coffee cup? Yeah, those could be a bit stronger. So it's time to build strength in your upper body—in the hands, wrists, arms, shoulders, chest, and core. It is based around Sun Salutation, a yoga sequence that builds strength, increases power, and improves endurance.

prospects.name: Core Strengtheners I
prospects.description: The power to to put watts to the pedals comes not just from your legs, but from your core. When your core is strong and stable, you can generate more power, more efficiently. You'll also suffer less back pain. With those goals in mind, this sequence strengthens the abs, obliques, and lower back.

prospects.name: Super Easy Stretch Routine I
prospects.description: Are you looking for a simple stretching routine you can do on a regular basis? New to yoga? Designed for yoga beginners, this gentle yoga session will get you on the road to a more flexible you. You've said for years you'd start stretching. Now's your chance.

prospects.name: One Hour Total Body Stretch
prospects.description:
This one-hour total body stretch includes 25 poses, starting with the upper body to stretch the neck, shoulders, chest, and forearms, then progressing to the lower back, glutes, groin, hip flexors, quads, hamstrings, calves, and ankles. It is an excellent routine to practice before bed to release tension in partially-contracted muscles and correct alignment. Deep relaxation into each pose, combined with nasal breathing and extended exhalations, enhances the stretch's intensity.

​

The objectives are to deeply relax the body and mind, loosen the neck and shoulders, increase spinal mobility, open up the hips (including the hip flexors, groin, glutes, and piriformis), stretch the calves and hamstrings, improve the range of motion in the feet and ankles, and potentially alleviate lower back pain.

​

The session guides you through a series of lunges and finishes with Lizard and Pigeon pose. You can practice it in the morning, before or after a ride. Experiment to see what works best for you.

prospects.description: This therapeutic session stretches the hip muscles in all directions to ease pain and stiffness in the pelvis and lower back.  It’s a great one to practice after your run or before bed to ensure that you wake up feeling supple and pain-free.

prospects.name: Core Strengtheners II
prospects.description: Building on the gains you've achieved after doing the Core Strengtheners exercises several times, this session further strengthens the core.

This sequence can be practiced at any time of day.

​

This hip-opening sequence is particularly effective for stretching the calves, hamstrings, groin, hip flexors, and quads. It's ideal for practicing after a workout or in the evening to increase flexibility and loosen up the hips.

The objectives are to stretch the calves, hamstrings, groin, hip flexors, and quads; open up the hips; and trigger a parasympathetic nervous system response.

**Poses in this session:**

prospects.description:
This classic yoga sequence enhances mobility in the spine and hips while stretching the calves, hamstrings, hip flexors, and lower back. As you become familiar with the routine, you can begin to focus on synchronizing your breath with your movements, aiming to use nasal breathing as much as possible. It is an excellent practice for the morning to warm up and improve focus, or it can be done directly after a workout to help prevent extreme muscle stiffness.

The objectives are to improve mobility in the spine and hips, stretch the calves, hamstrings, hip flexors, and lower back, practice synchronizing breath and movement, and potentially alleviate lower back pain.
